description: The MITA 4.0 Capability Reference Model defines the capabilities that State Medicaid Agencies (SMAs) possess or seek to develop. Capabilities are organized into three layers: Strategic (enterprise strategy), Core (mission and outcomes), and Support (critical enablers). Each capability is assessed using the standardized ORBIT maturity criteria.

domains.name: Plan and Policy Management
domains.description: The Plan and Policy Management domain covers health plan and health benefits administration.

areas.name: Health Plan Administration
areas.description: Manage the rates and health plan information for Medicaid that will be applied in the future.

areas.name: Health Benefits Administration
areas.description: Includes the development and implementation of health benefit packages to accommodate service delivery to targeted member populations. The SMA determines benefit terms, limitations, and applicable periods for services.

domains.name: Strategy and Planning Management
domains.description: The Strategy and Planning Management domain covers strategic planning, agency roadmap development, and state plan administration.

areas.name: Maintain Strategic Plan
areas.description: Ensures that a state's Medicaid enterprise remains aligned with its long-term strategic vision while adapting to evolving needs and priorities. Allows for alignment of outcomes and measures at the enterprise level.

areas.name: Develop Agency Roadmap
areas.description: The SMA's roadmap serves a critical function of monitoring and managing the agency's portfolio, projects, and initiatives against federal funding (APDs), architectural vision, goals, and outcomes.

areas.name: State Plan Administration
areas.description: Administration of the state plan in alignment with MITA facilitates the desired relationship between the SMA's policy and strategic planning. This collaboration promotes the connection between policy and funding, architecture, and performance monitoring.

domains.name: Business Relationship Management
domains.description: The Business Relationship Management domain covers managing and monitoring business relationships throughout their lifecycle.

areas.name: Manage Business Relationship Lifecycle
areas.description: Ability to define the exchange of information and Trading Partner Agreements (TPA) between the SMA and its partners, including collaboration among intrastate agencies, interstate agencies, and federal agencies. These agreements address functionality for interoperability, coordination of standards of interoperability, establishment of inter-agency Service Level Agreements (SLA), identification of the types of information exchanged, and security and privacy requirements. Has a common focus (e.g., data exchange standards and SLA) and is responsible for the business relationship data store.

areas.name: Monitor Business Relationship
areas.description: Ability to collect, organize, modify, and report on information about relationships with business partners, including monitoring significant dates, SLAs, points of contact, and limitations or constraints.

domains.name: Care and Service Coordination
domains.description: The Care and Service Coordination domain covers waiver management, long-term care, visit verification, case management, and prior authorization processes.

areas.name: Waiver Management
areas.description: Medicaid waivers allow a state to waive certain Medicaid eligibility requirements, such as covering care for people who might not otherwise be eligible for Medicaid. A waiver support system could be any enhancement to a MES module that helps the SMA facilitate changes to the Medicaid program operationalized by an approved waiver.

areas.name: Long-Term Care Support Management
areas.description: Medicaid is the primary payer across the nation for long-term care services. Medicaid allows for the coverage of these services through several vehicles and over a continuum of settings, ranging from institutional care to community-based long-term services and supports (LTSS).

areas.name: Visit Verification Monitoring
areas.description: Electronic Visit Verification (EVV) electronically documents and verifies service delivery information, such as date, time, service type and location, for certain Medicaid service visits that occur in the beneficiary's home.

areas.name: Case Management
areas.description: Manage Cases that use state-specific criteria and rules to ensure appropriate and cost-effective medical, medically-related social and behavioral health services are identified, planned, obtained and monitored for individuals identified as eligible for care management services under such programs as: Medicaid Waiver program case management, Home and Community-Based Services (HCBS), Other agency programs, Disease management, Catastrophic cases, Early Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment (EPSDT), and Immunizations for children and adults.

areas.name: Prior Authorization
areas.description: Confirms authorization for services that require prior approval to manage costs or ensure patient safety, and that the services provided are consistent with the authorization. The system accepts use of the authorization by multiple sequential providers during the period as allowed by state rules. Prior-authorization records stored by the system are correctly associated with the relevant claim(s).

domains.name: Claims and Encounter Management
domains.description: The Claims and Encounter Management domain covers claims submission, adjudication, encounter processing, adjustments, and lifecycle management.

areas.name: Claims and Encounter Submission Management
areas.description: Covers the end-to-end intake for both claims and encounter data, including: receiving submissions from providers, MCOs, and clearinghouses; validating data formats and compliance with standards (e.g., HIPAA, NPI); and logging and routing submissions for downstream processing. Ensures that all incoming data is clean, complete, and ready for adjudication or analysis. Serves as the entry point into the Medicaid Enterprise System for service-related transactions.

areas.name: Claims Adjudication
areas.description: Focuses on the evaluation and determination of submitted claims for payment. Applies Medicaid policy rules, benefit plan logic, provider contracts, and pricing algorithms to assess claim validity and calculate payment amounts. The adjudication process also includes edits for duplicate claims, service limits, and medical necessity. Once adjudicated, claims are either approved, denied, or pended, and remittance advice is generated for provider communication.

areas.name: Encounter Processing
areas.description: Manages the validation, transformation, and analysis of encounter data submitted by managed care entities. Ensures that encounter records meet quality and completeness standards and are suitable for use in utilization tracking, quality measurement, and federal reporting (e.g., Transformed Medicaid Statistical Information System [T-MSIS]). Supports the integrity of managed care oversight by ensuring that encounter data accurately reflects services rendered to Medicaid beneficiaries.

areas.name: Claims and Encounters Adjustments
areas.description: Supports the correction and reprocessing of previously submitted claims and encounters. It includes handling adjustments, voids, and resubmissions due to errors, policy changes, or appeals. Maintains a full audit trail of all versions and ensures that reprocessed items are adjudicated or analyzed appropriately. Essential for maintaining data accuracy, supporting provider dispute resolution, and ensuring compliance with audit and oversight requirements.

areas.name: Claims and Encounters Lifecycle Management
areas.description: Provides comprehensive tracking and oversight of the status and performance of claims and encounters throughout their lifecycle. Includes real-time status updates, error tracking, and resolution workflows, as well as operational analytics and performance monitoring. Supports transparency for internal users and external stakeholders, and enables timely interventions, reporting (including preparation and submission of data to T-MSIS), and continuous improvement in processing efficiency and data quality.

domains.name: Contract Management
domains.description: The Contract Management domain encompasses contract lifecycle management, contractor management, contract information management, and grievance/appeal processes.

areas.name: Contract Lifecycle Management
areas.description: Supports lifecycle management of contracts from initiation and negotiation through execution, monitoring, and renewal while ensuring alignment with program objectives and regulatory standards.

areas.name: Contractor Management
areas.description: Manage all Medicaid contractors through the award, assessment, and closeout of contracts that support the SMA. Provides ability to analyze and address contractors' operational needs throughout their engagement, including the ability to identify, assemble, and make available tools and information to help contractors be more successful in supporting Medicaid operations.

areas.name: Contract Information Management
areas.description: Maintain and manage comprehensive contract and contractor information to ensure effective oversight by the SMA. Includes capturing, organizing, and monitoring all contractual elements such as SLAs, performance outcomes, compliance requirements, and formal agreements.

areas.name: Contractor Grievance and Appeal
areas.description: The ability to process and resolve contractor grievances and appeals.

domains.name: Financial Management
domains.description: The Financial Management domain encompasses accounts receivable, accounts payable, fiscal/budget management, fund management, third party liability, and financial information management.

areas.name: Accounts Payable
areas.description: Enables SMA management of financial transactions related to Medicaid payments, including auditing, processing, and reconciling payables.

areas.name: Accounts Receivable
areas.description: Enables an SMA's tracking, management, and reconciliation of incoming payments and obligations owed to the Medicaid program.

areas.name: Fiscal / Budget Management
areas.description: Ability to formulate and manage budgets.

areas.name: Fund Management
areas.description: Ability to receive, manage, and allocate Medicaid funds, ensuring the accurate, effective use of the funds for the benefit of members.

areas.name: Third-Party Liability
areas.description: Ability to identify sources of revenue such as third-party liability, estate recovery, rebates, and other recoverable funds.

areas.name: Financial Information Management
areas.description: Ability to collect, manage, and report on financial information about the SMA.

domains.name: Member Management
domains.description: The Member Management domain covers member eligibility, enrollment, and support management processes.

areas.name: Member Eligibility Management
areas.description: Supports the submission and processing of applications for eligibility for new members, as well as ongoing eligibility-related activities.

areas.name: Member Enrollment Management
areas.description: Supports enrollment of eligible members and ongoing enrollment-related support functions. Includes assignment to an appropriate MCO or Fee-for-Service plan based on eligibility, member health needs, and other relevant factors.

areas.name: Member Support Management
areas.description: Supports the submission and resolution of member grievances and appeals, maintenance and availability of member information, and communication to existing and potential members of relevant program changes and requirements.

domains.name: Pharmacy Management
domains.description: The Pharmacy Management domain covers pharmacy benefit administration and drug monitoring oversight.

areas.name: Pharmacy Benefit Administration
areas.description: Standardized formulary, Prior Authentication, claims adjudication, rebate, network, and member support processes using Pharmacy Benefit Management (PBM)/Medicaid Management Information System (MMIS) functions. Supports consistent reporting on utilization and spend.

areas.name: Drug Monitoring Oversight
areas.description: Enables routine, repeatable oversight of controlled substance monitoring with standard reporting and Drug Utilization Review (DUR) processes. Supports structured audits for compliance.

domains.name: Provider Management
domains.description: The Provider Management capability domain encompasses provider enrollment, screening, monitoring, and support processes.

areas.name: Provider Enrollment
areas.description: Encompasses the required business processes and functions to register providers to participate in the Medicaid program and ensures that only qualified, eligible, and compliant providers are allowed to provide services to Medicaid clients. Includes the intake of new applications, updates to existing provider records, and removal of providers from the network when needed. Ensures provider data is accurate, validated, and aligned with state and federal regulations, while supporting continuity of care for Medicaid clients.

areas.name: Provider Screening
areas.description: Ensures that all providers meet the eligibility, screening, and compliance requirements necessary to participate in the Medicaid program. Includes validating professional licenses, certifications, education, training, work history, and conducting required screenings such as federal and state exclusion lists, criminal background checks, and site visits to confirm legitimacy and compliance with Medicaid standards. Applies during initial enrollment and on an ongoing basis to protect program integrity, reduce fraud, and safeguard Medicaid client access to qualified providers.

areas.name: Provider Monitoring
areas.description: Supports the continuous process of overseeing provider compliance and performance and maintaining current and accurate provider data. Includes periodic revalidation of provider eligibility, proactive monitoring of provider performance and risk indicators, and interventions when risk factors are identified. Ensures that providers remain compliant and program risk is mitigated as needed. Helps ensure that states maintain a compliant, effective, and reliable Medicaid provider network.

areas.name: Provider Support Management
areas.description: Provides a comprehensive, standardized capability for the SMA to support providers across the full lifecycle of interactions covering inquiries, onboarding support, training, technical assistance, complaints, grievances, and appeals. Ensures timely, consistent responses; fair resolution of disputes; and continuous improvement driven by performance analytics and stakeholder feedback.

domains.name: Compliance Management
domains.description: The Compliance Management domain covers program monitoring and performance evaluation processes.

areas.name: Program Monitoring Management
areas.description: Ability to monitor, audit, and track performance and behavior to determine the necessity, quality, and appropriateness of services, fraud and abuse, erroneous payments, and administrative abuses.

areas.name: Program Performance Evaluation
areas.description: Ability to evaluate the impact, performance, and costs associated with Medicaid programs, the SMA, partners (contractors/providers), and other associated parties.

domains.name: Communication Management
domains.description: The Communication Management domain covers communication development, dissemination, intake, and public affairs.

areas.name: Communication Development
areas.description: Ability to collect, organize, and otherwise prepare information as content to be communicated internally and externally, including the ability to draft and format the content as necessary for distribution.

areas.name: Communication Dissemination
areas.description: Ability to manage and distribute prepared communication content to the intended recipient(s) through various channels.

areas.name: Communication Intake
areas.description: Ability to receive communications from internal or external parties, ensure they are routed to the appropriate recipient(s), and satisfy any other handling requirements (e.g., privacy, confidentiality, storage/retention).

areas.name: Public Affairs
areas.description: Ability to exchange information and communications between the SMA, members, and stakeholders in direct support of healthcare services, policy, and resources.

domains.name: Data Management
domains.description: The Data Management Capability Domain represents the SMA's ability to manage its data. The domain encompasses key data management capability areas organized into Foundational (oversight and structure) and Lifecycle (data through planning, design, use, enhancement, enablement, and maintenance) categories.

categories.name: Foundational
categories.description: Data management capability areas that all other data management capability areas depend on and are critical for successfully managing data. These foundational capabilities provide oversight and structure to ensure data is fit for use and accessible to the right people.

areas.name: Data Governance
areas.description: Provides the ability to establish policies, roles, and processes to ensure data is managed as a strategic asset aligned with organizational objectives. Provides accountability and decision rights over data.
topics: Roles and Responsibilities (e.g., Data Steward and Data Owner)

areas.name: Data Quality
areas.description: Provides the ability to ensure that data is fit for use.

areas.name: Metadata Management
areas.description: Provides the ability to create, track, store, and maintain information about an SMA's data assets.

areas.name: Data Security & Privacy
areas.description: Provides the ability to protect data from unauthorized access and ensures compliance with privacy laws and regulations to maintain trust and safeguard sensitive information.

categories.name: Lifecycle
categories.description: Data management capability areas that support the management of data through one or more phases of its lifecycle. These capability areas support data through planning, design, use, enhancement, enablement, and maintenance.

areas.name: Master Data Management
areas.description: Provides the ability to manage critical business entities' data (e.g., customers and products) to ensure a single, authoritative view across the enterprise for consistency.

areas.name: Reference Data Management
areas.description: Provides the ability to manage shared, standardized data that is used to characterize or classify other data and to relate data to information internal and external to the SMA.

areas.name: Data Integration and Interoperability
areas.description: Provides the ability to seamlessly exchange data and consolidate it across diverse systems. Ensures data consistency and accessibility enterprise-wide and with trading partners.

areas.name: Data Storage and Warehousing
areas.description: Provides the ability to persistently store, retain, and manage data in a specific location that is accessible to authorized stakeholders.
topics: Machine Learning Readiness Structure / Unstructured Storage

areas.name: Data Architecture, Modeling, and Design
areas.description: Provides the ability to define data structures, models, and standards that support organizational data strategy and ensure data integrity and usability.

areas.name: Document and Content Management
areas.description: Provides the ability to capture, track, store, retain, and manage unstructured data such as documents and multimedia. Ensures efficient storage, retrieval, and compliance with retention policies.

areas.name: Business Intelligence & Data Science
areas.description: Provides the ability to collect, prepare, analyze, visualize, and present data to help SMAs make informed business decisions. Includes the ability to apply analytical techniques and advanced algorithms to transform data into actionable insights supporting strategic decision-making.

domains.name: Technical
domains.description: The Technical Capability Domain represents the SMA's technology capabilities that enable and support core and strategic capabilities. Organized into seven categories: Infrastructure, Integration, Platform Services, Application Architecture, Security and Identity, Operations and Maintenance, and Development and Release.

categories.name: Infrastructure
categories.description: Capabilities related to compute, storage, networking, and system resilience.

areas.name: Compute and Hosting
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to provision servers and cloud platforms for Medicaid systems and applications.

areas.name: Storage
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to manage Medicaid data storage, including files and backups for retention.

areas.name: Networking and Connectivity
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to enable secure connections between internal systems, external partners, and cloud environments.
topics: Secure Connections between Internal Systems and External Partners
Reliable Communication in Computing and Hosting Environments

areas.name: Resilience and Scaling
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to maintain system operation during outages through failover and disaster recovery or to make adjustments during peak usage.

categories.name: Integration
categories.description: Capabilities related to APIs, system messaging, and external partner connectivity.

areas.name: API and Interface Management
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to facilitate data sharing between systems using standard formats like FHIR, X12, or Representational State Transfer (REST).

areas.name: System Messaging
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to enable real-time or scheduled alerts or events between systems.
topics: Clear and Traceable Alerts or Events

areas.name: External Partner Integration
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to establish secure connections with CMS, MCOs, providers, and other federal or state partners.
topics: Secure Connections with CMS, MCOs, Providers

categories.name: Platform Services
categories.description: Capabilities related to application hosting, business rules, and shared platform functions.

areas.name: Application Hosting
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to host managed environments that run Medicaid applications.

areas.name: Business Rules and Workflow
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to create rules (such as eligibility criteria) and automate processes (like Provider Enrollment).

areas.name: Common Platform Functions
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to use shared services, such as address verification or file upload services, that multiple systems can use to prevent redundancy and duplication.

categories.name: Application Architecture
categories.description: Capabilities related to modular design, user interfaces, and session management.

areas.name: Modular Architecture
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to divide large Medicaid systems into smaller, manageable components for easier scaling and replacement.

areas.name: User Interfaces
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to design application screens that are easy to access, interact with, and consistent for users, such as members and providers.

areas.name: Session and State Management
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to monitor user activity during a session, enabling users to confidently and securely continue or finish their actions.

categories.name: Security and Identity
categories.description: Capabilities related to identity management, consent, data protection, and security monitoring.

areas.name: Identity and Access Services
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to control who can log in, what they can do, and how their identity is verified.

areas.name: Consent Management
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to gather and manage member consents and data-sharing preferences.

areas.name: System and Data Protection
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to use measures like encryption, firewalls, and secure configurations to prevent unauthorized access and protect sensitive Medicaid and healthcare data.
topics: Protection of Medicaid and Healthcare Data

areas.name: Security Monitoring
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to detect unusual activity, log events, and support audits to better comply with CMS and NIST security standards, e.g., Acceptable Risk Controls for Affordable Care Act (ACA), Medicaid, and Partner Entities (ARC-AMPE).
topics: Compliance with CMS and NIST Security Standards

categories.name: Operations and Maintenance
categories.description: Capabilities related to system monitoring and operations.

areas.name: Systems Monitoring
areas.description: Provides an SMA's visibility into Medicaid system health, including uptime, performance, and availability.

areas.name: Systems Operations
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to manage systems, perform tasks, and deploy updates across various environments.

categories.name: Development and Release
categories.description: Capabilities related to code management, testing, and security compliance in the development lifecycle.

areas.name: Code and Configuration Management
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to write, track, and securely manage software changes.

areas.name: Testing and Release
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to run tests to identify bugs or issues and deploy code across different environments such as Development, Test, and Production.
topics: Testing for Bugs, Issues, or Defects

areas.name: Security Compliance
areas.description: Provides the ability for SMAs to incorporate security checks throughout the development process to ensure code is secure.
